title-group.article-title: Interventions to reduce inpatient and discharge opioid prescribing for postpartum patients: a systematic review

sec.title: INTRODUCTION:
sec.p: As deaths related to opioids continue to rise, reducing opioid use for postpartum pain management is an important priority. Thus, we conducted a systematic review of postpartum interventions aimed at reducing opioid use following birth.

sec.title: METHODS:
sec.p: From database inception through 9/1/2021, we conducted a systematic search in Embase, Medline, Cochrane Library, and Scopus including the following MeSH terms: postpartum, pain management, opioid prescribing. Studies published in English, restricted to the United States, and evaluating interventions initiated following birth with outcomes including an assessment of change in opioid prescribing or use during the postpartum period (<8 weeks postpartum) were included. Authors independently screened abstracts and full articles for inclusion, extracted data, and assessed study quality using the Grading of Recommendations, Assessment, Development, and Evaluation tool and risk of bias using the Institutes of Health Quality Assessment Tools.

sec.title: RESULTS:
sec.p: A total of 24 studies met inclusion criteria. Sixteen studies evaluated interventions aimed at reducing postpartum opioid use during the inpatient hospitalization and 10 studies evaluated interventions aimed at reducing opioid prescribing at postpartum discharge. Inpatient interventions included changes to standard order-sets and protocols for the management of post-cesarean pain. Such interventions resulted in significant decreases in inpatient postpartum opioid use in all but one study. Additional inpatient interventions, including use of lidocaine patches, postoperative abdominal binder, valdecoxib, and acupuncture, were not found to be effective to reduce postpartum opioid use during inpatient hospitalization. Interventions targeting the postpartum period included individualized prescribing and state legislative changes limiting the duration of opioid prescribing for acute pain both resulted in decreased opioid prescribing or opioid use.

sec.title: DISCUSSION:
sec.p: A variety of interventions aimed at reducing opioid use following birth have shown efficacy. While it is not known if any single intervention is most effective, these data suggest that implementation of any number of interventions may be advantageous in reducing postpartum opioid use.

abstract.title: Precis:
abstract.p: In this systematic review, the majority of identified interventions aimed at reducing postpartum opioid use were effective in decreasing opioid prescribing and opioid use.
